section.t: Registry completes the request successfully and returns a favorable response.

section.title: Add TN Prefix
section.t: Next, SSP2 activates a block of ten thousand TNs using the TNPType structure and identifying a TN prefix.
Registry completes the request successfully and returns a favorable response.

section.title: Enable Peering -- Route Group Offer
section.t: In order for SSP1 to complete session establishment for a destination TN where the target subscriber has a retail relationship with SSP2, it first requires an asynchronous bi-directional handshake to show mutual consent. To start the process, SSP2 initiates the peering handshake by offering SSP1 access to its route group.

Registry completes the request successfully and confirms that the SSP1 will now have the opportunity to weigh in on the offer and either accept or reject it. The Registry may employ out-of-band notification mechanisms for quicker updates to SSP1 so they can act faster, though this topic is beyond the scope of this document.

section.title: Enable Peering -- Route Group Offer Accept
section.t: SSP1 responds to the offer from SSP2 and agrees to have visibility to SSP2 ingress routes.

Registry confirms that the request has been processed successfully. From this point forward, if SSP1 looks up a public identity through the query resolution server, where the public identity is part of the destination group by way of "RTE_GRP_SSP2_1" route association, SSP2 ingress SBE information will be shared with SSP1.

section.title: Add Egress Route
section.t: SSP1 wants to prioritize all outbound traffic to routes associated with "RTE_GRP_SSP2_1" route group through "sbe1.ssp1.example.com".
Since peering has already been established, the request to add the egress route has been successfully completed.

section.title: Get Destination Group
section.t: SSP2 uses the 'GetDestGrpsRqstType' operation to tally the last provisioned record for destination group DEST_GRP_SSP2_1.
Registry completes the request successfully and returns a favorable response.

section.title: Get Public Identity
section.t: SSP2 obtains the last provisioned record associated with a given TN.
Registry completes the request successfully and returns a favorable response.

section.title: Get Route Group Request
section.t: SSP2 obtains the last provisioned record for the route group RTE_GRP_SSP2_1.
Registry completes the request successfully and returns a favorable response.

section.title: Get Route Group Offers Request
section.t: SSP2 fetches the last provisioned route group offer to the <peeringOrg> SSP1.
Registry processes the request successfully and returns a favorable response.

section.title: Get Egress Route
section.t: SSP1 wants to verify the last provisioned record for the egress route called EGR_RTE_01.
Registry completes the request successfully and returns a favorable response.

section.title: Delete Destination Group
section.t: SSP2 initiates a request to delete the destination group DEST_GRP_SSP2_1.
Registry completes the request successfully and returns a favorable response.

section.title: Delete Public Identity
section.t: SSP2 choses to de-activate the TN and remove it from the Registry.
Registry completes the request successfully and returns a favorable response.

section.title: Delete Route Group Request
section.t: SSP2 removes the route group called RTE_GRP_SSP2_1.
Registry completes the request successfully and returns a favorable response.

section.title: Delete Route Group Offers Request
section.t: SSP2 no longer wants to share route group RTE_GRP_SSP2_1 with SSP1.

Registry completes the request successfully and returns a favorable response. Restoring this resource sharing will require a new route group offer from SSP2 to SSP1 followed by a successful route group accept request from SSP1.

section.title: Delete Egress Route
section.t: SSP1 decides to remove the egress route with the label EGR_RTE_01.
Registry completes the request successfully and returns a favorable response.

section.title: XML Considerations
section.t: XML serves as the encoding format for SPPP, allowing complex hierarchical data to be expressed in a text format that can be read, saved, and manipulated with both traditional text tools and tools specific to XML. XML is case sensitive. Unless stated otherwise, XML specifications and examples provided in this document MUST be interpreted in the character case presented to develop a conforming implementation. This section discusses a small number of XML-related considerations pertaining to SPPP.

section.title: Namespaces
section.t: All SPPP protocol elements are defined in the namespaces in the IANA Considerations section and in the Formal Protocol Specification section of this document.

section.title: Versioning and Character Encoding
section.t: All XML instances SHOULD begin with an <?xml?> declaration to identify the version of XML that is being used, optionally identify use of the character encoding used, and optionally provide a hint to an XML parser that an external schema file is needed to validate the XML instance. Conformant XML parsers recognize both UTF-8 (defined in ) and UTF-16 (defined in ); per UTF-8 is the RECOMMENDED character encoding for use with SPPP.

Character encodings other than UTF-8 and UTF-16 are allowed by XML. UTF-8 is the default encoding assumed by XML in the absence of an "encoding" attribute or a byte order mark (BOM); thus, the "encoding" attribute in the XML declaration is OPTIONAL if UTF-8 encoding is used. SPPP clients and servers MUST accept a UTF-8 BOM if present, though emitting a UTF-8 BOM is NOT RECOMMENDED.
Example XML declarations: <?xml?> version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="no"?>

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: The transport protocol section contains some security properties that the transport protocol must provide so that authenticated endpoints can exchange data confidentially and with integrity protection.
More details will be provided in a future revision of this document.
